Lees, J.P.; Wang, P.; Aubert, B.; Boutigny, D.; Karyotakis, Y.; Poireau, V.; Tisserand, V.; Zghiche, A.; Grauges, E.; Pappagallo, M.; Eigen, G.; Stugu, B. /Bergen U. /LBL, Berkeley /UC,; Zhu, Y.S.; Rong, G.; Qi, N.D.; Barate, R.; Pompili, A.; Couderc, F.; Ofte, I.; Palano, A.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="506" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Free-to-read</subfield><subfield code="f">Unrestricted online access</subfield><subfield code="2">star</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="520" ind1="3" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">The authors search for B⁻ → {tilde D}°K⁻ and B⁻ → {tilde D}*°K⁻, with {tilde D}*° → {tilde D}°π° or {tilde D}*° → {tilde D}°γ, and {tilde D}° → K⁺π⁻ (and charge conjugates). These final states can be reached through the b → c transition B⁻ → D{sup (*)0}K⁻ followed by the doubly CKM-suppressed D° → K⁺π⁻, or the b → u transition B⁻ → {bar D}{sup (*)0}K⁻ followed by the CKM-favored {bar D}° → K⁺π⁻. The interference of these two amplitudes is sensitive to the angle γ of the unitarity triangle. The results are based on 232 million Υ(4S) → B{bar B} decays collected with the BABAR detector at SLAC. They find no significant evidence for these decays. They set a limit r{sub B} {triple_bond} </subfield><subfield code="a">(B⁻ → {bar D}°K⁻)/A(B⁻ → D°K⁻)</subfield><subfield code=" ">< 0.23 at 90% C.L. using the most conservative assumptions on the values of the CKM angle γ and the strong phases in the B and D decay amplitudes. In the case of the D* they set a 90% C.L. limit r*{sub B}² {triple_bond} </subfield><subfield code="a">(B⁻ → {bar D}*°K⁻)/A(B⁻ → D*° K⁻)</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="536" ind1=" " ind2=" "slac-pub-11137" "hep-ex/0504047" Phys.Rev.D72:032004,2005 FT Chen, J.C.; Lees, J.P.; Wang, P.; Aubert, B.; Boutigny, D.; Karyotakis, Y.; Poireau, V.; Tisserand, V.; Zghiche, A.; Grauges, E.; Pappagallo, M.; Eigen, G.; Stugu, B. /Bergen U. /LBL, Berkeley /UC,; Zhu, Y.S.; Rong, G.; Qi, N.D.; Barate, R.; Pompili, A.; Couderc, F.; Ofte, I.; Palano, A. Free-to-read Unrestricted online access star The authors search for B⁻ → {tilde D}°K⁻ and B⁻ → {tilde D}*°K⁻, with {tilde D}*° → {tilde D}°π° or {tilde D}*° → {tilde D}°γ, and {tilde D}° → K⁺π⁻ (and charge conjugates). These final states can be reached through the b → c transition B⁻ → D{sup (*)0}K⁻ followed by the doubly CKM-suppressed D° → K⁺π⁻, or the b → u transition B⁻ → {bar D}{sup (*)0}K⁻ followed by the CKM-favored {bar D}° → K⁺π⁻. The interference of these two amplitudes is sensitive to the angle γ of the unitarity triangle. The results are based on 232 million Υ(4S) → B{bar B} decays collected with the BABAR detector at SLAC. They find no significant evidence for these decays. They set a limit r{sub B} {triple_bond}  (B⁻ → {bar D}°K⁻)/A(B⁻ → D°K⁻) < 0.23 at 90% C.L. using the most conservative assumptions on the values of the CKM angle γ and the strong phases in the B and D decay amplitudes. In the case of the D* they set a 90% C.L. limit r*{sub B}² {triple_bond}  (B⁻ → {bar D}*°K⁻)/A(B⁻ → D*° K⁻) AC02-76SF00515 Particle Accelerators. edbsc Amplitudes. Decay Amplitudes. notes_summary_ssim: The authors search for B⁻ → {tilde D}°K⁻ and B⁻ → {tilde D}*°K⁻, with {tilde D}*° → {tilde D}°π° or {tilde D}*° → {tilde D}°γ, and {tilde D}° → K⁺π⁻ (and charge conjugates). These final states can be reached through the b → c transition B⁻ → D{sup (*)0}K⁻ followed by the doubly CKM-suppressed D° → K⁺π⁻, or the b → u transition B⁻ → {bar D}{sup (*)0}K⁻ followed by the CKM-favored {bar D}° → K⁺π⁻. The interference of these two amplitudes is sensitive to the angle γ of the unitarity triangle. The results are based on 232 million Υ(4S) → B{bar B} decays collected with the BABAR detector at SLAC. They find no significant evidence for these decays. They set a limit r{sub B} {triple_bond}  (B⁻ → {bar D}°K⁻)/A(B⁻ → D°K⁻) (B⁻ → {bar D}*°K⁻)/A(B⁻ → D*° K⁻)
